Description: Bust of Caracalla, radiate and cuirassed, right, seen from front. (obverse)
Serapis standing left, holding sistrum in right hand and vertical sceptre in left hand. (reverse)
State: Associated with: Roman Empire Ancient Greece and Rome: Roman Empire
Curator's comments: It has been suggested that Caracalla honoured Serapis on his late coinage in reference to the imperial visit to Egypt in AD 215. However, since he also appears on Caracalla's coinage earlier in the reign, and given Severus' professed enthusiasm for the god, it was probably also a family devotion. Serapis was a syncretic god created in Ptolemaic Egypt and was designed to be inclusive to both Greeks and Egyptians by containing attributes of other gods such as Osiris, Zeus, Hades, and Asklepios.
Bibliographic references: RE5 / Coins of the Roman Empire in the British Museum, vol.V: Pertinax to Elagabalus (187, p.464)
RIC4 / The Roman imperial coinage, vol. 4: Pertinax - Uranius Antonius (289e, p.255) (var.)
Acquisition notes: The Bank of England loaned their Collection to the British Museum in 1865 wishing to make it accessible to the general public. This remained as a separate Collection until 1877 when the Bank Directors decided it would be more useful to the museum and the public if incorporated into the national collection. The Bank of England collection was therefore presented to the British Museum in 1877, any duplicates being sold to create a coins and medals purchase fund.
